transcripts.text: How are you guys doing?  Good.  Hi, everybody.  Listen, everybody, thank you so much for joining us again.  We're just so excited that you got to participate.  You know, when we started ASP, the whole idea was just to find a place where folks who get to sync answers and help engage with their electorate and and hopefully be moved to be more involved and have conversations around things that matter.  I'd say, Chris, one of the cooler things about working with CloseUp is they brought you all to the table, which are first-time voters.  that are the people that really people need to hear from, not, quite frankly, Chris or I.

Well, first, we're really excited to be doing this with MTV, who has been committed to both our engagement for as long as I can remember, even when I was a little kid watching MTV commercials where I always blasted all over TV around this time.  So we're proud to be partnering with them and you lovely folks on National Vote Early Day.
Is that what it is today?
National Vote Early Day?
National Vote Early Day.
Great, great.  We'll do this now.  Now we should dive in.

Mark, take it away.  All right, so speaking of that, so in 2016, right, I think less than 50% of all the young Americans between the ages of 18 and 29 voted.  So let's start with you, Aldo.  Do you think that's going to happen again?  Are people more engaged and more excited this year than they were in 2016?

So to answer this question, yes, I really do think that young people are excited to vote.  I'm thinking about my hometown back in New York and my family.  as well as in Indianapolis.  I grew up in both of these cities and just all of my friends on social media and in person, students that you wouldn't think about voting are just excited and talking about these issues, which I did not see back in 2016.  So yes, I do believe there's going to be students turning out.
Fingers crossed.

Fingers crossed in a big way.  Jay, good to see you again.  I have a question for you.  And actually, we'll throw it out to a couple people, Jay and Dominic as well.  What's the issue that inspired you guys to vote this year?

Well, I think there are a couple of issues for me.  One of the big ones that I think I discussed with you both last time was climate change.  And just in general, voting for politicians who will advocate for measures that effectively combat climate change and also acknowledge the scientific evidence we have relating to, like, the need to combat climate change.  So I think that's one of my big issues.  And then also the reality is that the Supreme Court battle and the election are very intertwined this year.  And the fact that Amy Cotton Barrett hasn't actually taken a stance on whether or not she will vote to repeal Roe v. Wade makes, I think, gender equality another big issue in this election.  So even though it might not directly influence it, that is, like, another issue that's definitely driving me to vote this year.

I definitely agree with what Jaya said.  And I think for me, one big thing that's making me really excited about voting is how racial equity is popping up on the candidates' positions.  I think that right now we've certainly seen sort of a – we're starting to really think about it and we're starting to really analyze it.  the inequities within our nation.  And I think that racial equity is so tied in with healthcare and with climate justice and with gender equality.  And there are so many things that racial equity encompasses.  And so that's a really big issue for me when I'm voting.  And I think, especially with COVID-19 and people being unemployed, housing is another big thing.  Seeing how how federal funding is going into housing.  I want to be an urban planner.  That's what I'm going to school for.  And so seeing how candidates want to allocate funding to end sort of these discriminatory housing policies, which we're seeing which are very closely tied in to issues of racial equity and sort of exasperated by COVID-19 and seeing more people unemployed.

So jumping on that, Dominic, Sydney, so people talk a lot about you know, issues on a large scale.  They're interested in the environment.  They're interested in social justice.  But kind of along the lines of what Dominic was saying, what are specific things that affect you on a daily life that you talk about with your friends that are going to bring you to the polls, things that you experience at your age and with your peer group?

Yeah.  So I think one of the big things for me is I'm a woman in STEM.  And so I've dealt a lot with gender equality, gender equity and working in high school.  A lot of my goals were to.  I want to bring opportunities.  I want to bridge the gaps between inequities that prevent students from finding their passions in education.  That may prevent students from going to a club they really love because they don't have transportation.  Stuff that makes students like.  really want to go to school.  And so stuff like that has been really hit home for me.  Right now in college, I'm currently working in a lab, and one of my favorite projects is we're teaching teachers how to have these difficult conversations with students.  So I think stuff like that, they can understand what maybe their peers are going through.  If we can help teachers address these inequities that may hinder a child's education, That's probably one of the most important things for me.  But everyone has a different experience, and everyone can relate to this in some way, shape, or form.  That's amazing.

I think it's amazing that your idea is for you to help the teachers teach you all how to have better conversations around issues.  If that's not a sign that we need help from the unit to make sure that they're engaged, I don't know what is.
That's fantastic.
All right, I got one.
Jay or Aldo, how do you guys – where do you pull your information?  Before you guys go to vote, where do you guys go to educate yourselves?

I think that it's really important to look at a variety of news sources this year, because I mean, if I'm being honest, like when I'm scrolling on social media, sure, different pieces of information come up.  But it's really important to me to fact check those with organizations that I can trust to be reputable, maybe the New York Times or Reuters or other nonpartisan organizations that can confirm whether or not something is true or false.  And then in terms of platforms that have been really useful for specifically learning more about the candidates that are up for election, I know Ballotopedia was a great resource for me when I was filling out my ballot to just like see, okay, like these are the amendments on my ballot.  Like these are the proposed charters.  These are the candidates.  So I can like research them based on that or looking actually at a starting point after our first conversation, it was a great resource to be able to like see information from both sides.
Well, thank you.

So along those lines, looking up things for your ballot, a lot of people are talking this year about a voting plan.  It's not something we've heard a lot about or I hadn't heard a lot about in previous years.  Dominic, specifically due to COVID or because you're in college, is that something that you've dealt with?  Have you voted yet?  Are you looking to make a voting plan?  Do you hear your peers talk about what a voting plan might be?

Yeah.  So I actually, I have voted.  I am from Charlottesville and I go to University of Virginia, which is in Charlottesville.  And so I was able to pretty easily get to my early voting location.  And I am excited about voting plans.  I've been able to help some people register to vote, which has been exciting to be a part of that process in my new school.  And then I I've also made plans since I'm from here and I can get access to my car to drive some people to the voting locations for early voting because definitely a lot of people in my circle at least are talking about early voting.
I don't know about you, Chris, but as inspired as we get, I also feel old because I think about my first time voting.
Yeah, ancient.
Mine was, I hate to say this, I can't believe I'm gonna say it out loud, but mine was, my first presidential election I voted for was in 1992 for President Clinton in the first Georgia election.
You're much older than me, all right.
So I did, I think I was in college, you know, and it was just a different set of issues.

It was wild, and to hear how you guys are.  There wasn't any conversation on campus the way you guys are planning and thought about how the fact that I went to school away from where I was registered originally and what I had to do to get there.  So it's really neat to hear that you guys are thinking about that stuff and figuring out how to deal with the reality of your situation.

Every time I speak with you guys, I feel so inspired.  I mean, it really does bring me a sense of confidence knowing that there's this much focus and motivation between coming from the next generation.  And I don't know, this is just so fantastic.  I think we should really thank Close Up for doing this with us.  I know Close Up has been dedicated to getting civic engagement year round for a long time now and to MTV.  So thank you to all you guys and thank you for what you're doing.  And please, please stick with it because we need you.

Yeah, and for those of you at home, if you haven't voted yet, please try and vote early.  If you need to know more about voting, go to astartingpoint.com.  You can see any resource you need to figure out how to get your ballot or where to go to vote or get any more information to get engaged.  Thank you all so much.
We really appreciate it.
Lovely to see all of you.  Great work.  You guys are my heroes.  I love you all.  Mwah.  Thanks, guys.
